This dataset represents the treatment of non-exhaust emissions produced by average passenger car tyre abrasion. The datasets are treatments because they represent a removal of substances from the technosphere (removal of tyre material). This dataset is valid for Europe and represents the average data for the operation of average passenger car. Calculation of non-exhaust emissions (tyre, brake and road wear emissions as well as petrol evaporation emissions) are based on: Ntziachristos, L., Boulter, P. (2009b). EMEP/EEA air pollutant emissions inventory guidebook 2009: Road vehicle tyre and brake wear; Road surface wear. Copenhagen, European Environment Agency. The emission factors relate to 1kg tyre wear. The quantity of tyre wear emissions per kg vehicle and km is defined in the transport datasets. The tyre wear emissions are to air, water and soil. All particulates are accounted for as emissions to air and have particle sizes below 100um. Anything above this does not remain airborne over longer periods. Total particulates equals total of all air emission substances. The fractions to water and soil are calculated by deducting the airborne emissions from the total tyre wear. This remaining amount is then simply split 50/50 between water and soil.

The activity starts with the abrasion of passenger cart tyres on the road

The activity ends with emissions of passenger car tyre wear
